metadata.case_name: Damodar Valley Corporation v. State of Bihar

facts.text: The appellant is a Corporation incorporated under the Damodar Valley Corporation Act XIV of 1948. It is a multipurpose Corporation, one of its objects being the construction of a number of dams in Bihar and Bengal with a view to controlling floods and utilising the stored water for purposes of generation of electricity. One of such dams is the Konar Dam in the district of Hazaribagh in Bihar.

For the construction of the Konar Dam the Corporation entered into an agreement with Messrs Hind Construction Ltd. and Messrs Patel Engineering Co. Ltd. on May 24, 1950, and appointed them contractors for the aforesaid purpose.

As a result of a change in the design of the Dam, it became necessary to enter into a supplementary agreement and on March 10, 1951, cl. 8 of Part II of the original agreement was amended and a fresh cl. 8 was substituted.

Under the new cl. 8 of the agreement, as amended, the Corporation agreed to make available to the contractors such equipment as was necessary and suitable for the construction aforesaid. The Contractors are charged the actual price paid by the Corporation for the equipment and machinery thus made available, inclusive of freight and customs duty, if any, as also the cost of transport, but excluding sales tax.

The equipment thus supplied by the Corporation to the Contractors was classified into two groups, Group A and Group B, as detailed in Schedule No. 2. The machinery in Group A was to be taken over from the Contractors by the Corporation, after the completion of the work at their residual value which was to be calculated in the manner set out in the agreement. The machinery in Group B was to become the property of the Contractors after its full price had been paid by them. No dispute about Group B.
On August 12, 1952, the Superintendent of Sales Tax, Hazaribagh, assessed the Corporation under s. 13(5) of the Bihar Sales Tax Act, 1947 for the period April, 1950 to March, 1952.

The Corporation appealed to the Deputy Commissioner of Sales Tax. By his order dated May 5, 1953, the Deputy Commissioner rejected the contention of the appellant as to its liability under the Act, held that the supply of equipment in Group A amounted to a sale and was not a hire, that the condition for taking over was a condition of repurchase, and that the Corporation was a dealer.

The Corporation moved the Board of Revenue, Bihar, in its revisional jurisdiction under s. 24 of the Act. The Board of Revenue by its resolution dated October 1, 1953, rejected the revisional application and upheld the order of the authorities below.

The Corporation made an application to the Board of Revenue under s. 25 of the Act for a reference to the High Court. Questions referred initially: (a) whether assessment under s.13(5) maintainable; (b) whether property in goods in Schedule A passed to Contractors and transaction amounted to sale; (c) whether terms amount to sale and taking over amounts to repurchase. On May 20, 1954, questions (a) and (c) withdrawn, only (b) referred.
Patna High Court (Ramaswami, C.J. and Raj Kishore Prasad, J.) by judgment dated July 13, 1956, answered question (b) in the affirmative: transaction amounted to a sale within s.2(g) of the Act.
Corporation applied for certificate under Art. 132(1) Constitution. High Court by order dated January 31, 1957 dismissed, holding no substantial question of law as to interpretation of Constitution.
Supreme Court granted special leave to appeal under Art. 136 on March 31, 1958.

legal_issues.text: Whether, in the facts and circumstances of the case, it can be held that the property in the goods included in Schedule A did pass to the Contractors and the transaction amounted to a sale within the meaning of s.2(g) of the Bihar Sales Tax Act, 1947.

petitioner_arguments.text: The transaction in question did not amount to a sale within the meaning of the Act; it was a mere contract of hiring.

respondent_arguments.text: The supply of equipment in Group A amounted to a sale and was not a hire; the condition in the agreement for the taking over of the equipment was in essence a condition of repurchase; the Corporation was a dealer within the meaning of the Act.

court_reasoning.text: Additional grounds raised by appellant (Corporation not a dealer; proviso to s.2(g) ultra vires; Act ultra vires entry 48 List II Govt of India Act 1935) not open as never raised before authorities or High Court; appeal limited to referred question.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Scope of appeal by special leave cannot extend beyond scope of controversy that could have been raised before High Court.

court_reasoning.text: Analyzed terms of cl.8: equipment remains property of Corporation until full price realised; distinction from hire (which includes interest and depreciation); Corporation to take over Group A at residual value on conditions (proper maintenance, residual life not below 1/3 standard life, after work completion or earlier if surplus); Contractors pay full price in 18 instalments, at least 2/3 unconditionally; no right in Contractors to return at any time; Contractors maintain machine cards, good condition, cannot remove until full cost recovered; Contractors responsible for spares.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Agreement contemplates supply of machinery (not mere hire) with conditional repurchase.

court_reasoning.text: Tests: (1) no binding obligation on hirer to purchase? Here, bound to pay 2/3 price. (2) right reserved to return goods? No such right. Thus, sale with condition of repurchase. Substance over form; inconsistent with mere hiring (owner would handle spares/depreciation).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Title passed to Contractors subject to repurchase conditions.

holdings.text: The transaction in question amounted to a sale within the meaning of s.2(g) of the Bihar Sales Tax Act, 1947.

precedents_cited.relevance: If right reserved to hirer to return goods at any time, no contract of sale.

statutes_cited.name: Bihar Sales Tax Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of sale; assessment; revision; reference to High Court. Transaction is sale under s.2(g).

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal denied; special leave granted.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act, 1935
sections: entry 48 in List II of Schedule 7
statutes_cited.relevance: Mentioned in additional ground not entertained.

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave dismissed. High Court's answer affirmed: transaction regarding Group A machinery is a sale within s.2(g) Bihar Sales Tax Act. Additional grounds not entertained as beyond scope of reference.

key_quotes.text: The scope of the appeal to this Court, even by special leave, cannot be extended beyond the scope of the controversy that could have been legally raised before the High Court.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits appeal to referred question only.

key_quotes.text: One of the tests... is whether there is any binding obligation on the hirer to purchase the goods. Another useful test... is whether there is a right reserved to the hirer to return the goods at any time during the subsistence of the contract.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key tests applied to determine sale vs hire.

key_quotes.text: Applying these two tests to the transaction in the present case, it becomes clear that it was a case of sale of goods with a condition of repurchase on certain conditions.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on nature of transaction.
